paper_metadata.title: How Does a Rural Poverty Alleviation Program Affect Parents' Expectations About Their Children? Evidence from BRAC-TUP in Bangladesh

component_a_cash_support.cash_evidence_citation: d) weekly cash stipends for the first 40 weeks after the asset is transferred

component_b_assets.assets_evidence_citation: a) the transfer of productive assets, mainly a combination of different livestock packages (including cows, goats, and poultry) valued at approximately USD$560 in PPP terms

study_characteristics.outcomes_evidence_citation: We measure impacts on expectations, although we use the same strategy for other outcomes, such as enrollment or dropout rates
study_characteristics.design_evidence_citation: The selection process for BRAC-TUP uses a series of steps, following a randomized control trial (RCT) at the BRAC branch level

bonus_information.cost_mentions: Asset transfer valued at USD$560 in PPP terms
bonus_information.cost_evidence_citation: the transfer of productive assets, mainly a combination of different livestock packages (including cows, goats, and poultry) valued at approximately USD$560 in PPP terms

evidence_citations.program_name_citation: This study evaluates BRAC's Targeting the Ultra Poor (TUP) program in Bangladesh
evidence_citations.country_citation: This study evaluates BRAC's Targeting the Ultra Poor (TUP) program in Bangladesh
evidence_citations.target_population_citation: The program targets only the Ultra poor households (who represent around 6% of the country's total population)
